content.description: Clip the first bolt and then climb left.
content.location: This is the middle of three routes on this section of Pitbull Cliff.

content.description: This is a nice moderate climb with gray painted hangers. Climb a steep section, and finish on the left side of the arete.
content.location: It is the rightmost of the the three bolted routes on the right side of the Lower Pitbull Cliff (the routes closest to the parking lot). Look for the gray painted hangers.

content.description:
Start in the tan corner as for

Hot Dog

, but move hard left, and climb the face just right of the arete. Finish at the

TNT

anchor.
content.location:
Climb the same start as

Hot Dog

, but move left.

content.description:
Just left of the

TNT

start, stay left of a block/flake feature sticking out of the wall, and gain the bolted face that climbs in the corner before moving left on to the face, staying on the right edge of the arete and gaining the bolted anchor at the lip.
content.location:
Just left of

TNT

, stay left of a block/flake feature sticking out of the wall.

content.description: Climb through the wildly overhanging bottom section that traverses hard to the right, protected by the first three bolts. Then, gain a small alcove by mantling onto this mildly sloping shelf. Rest, and continue through a cruxy finish on small holds on the smooth, sheer face that guards the anchors. This is a short route, but it packs a punch.
content.location:
Located on the right side of the Lower Pitbull Cliff, it is currently the middle of three bolted routes. It is 10-20 feet right of

Little, Black Book

. Look for a steep overhang at the bottom and a sheer face above. There is a large block at the base of this overhang at the start.

content.description:
Just left of the

Practice Slab

cracks, climb the tan corner with a crux down low, stemming in the corner, and end with a steep finish with a roof to gain the anchor.

Climb the corner with tan rock and a hard pull off the ground, finishing with a roof below the anchor.
content.location:
Just left of the

Practice Slab

cracks/alcove, this is the bolted line in the tan corner.

content.description: Scramble up onto a large, detached flake, and follow 3 bolts up the black corner/dihedral using a variety of techniques.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a double bolt anchor.
content.location: Pitbull Cliff has two main sections. This is the leftmost route of the section closest to the parking lot. Scramble up talus, and start on a detached flake.

content.description: Climb a slab past three bolts to the sport anchors.  Great movement!
content.protection: 3 bolts, sport anchors. A walkoff is possible.
content.location: This is the farthest route to the left on Pitbull Cliff. Start "fumunda" a pine tree.  This is one of three routes that are located around the corner from Pitbull proper.  It requires a bushwhack down and through some swampy terrain in the summer.

content.description: You can ascend the Practice Slab in a few different ways, all being moderate. A variety of cracks can be used, and it's also feasible to climb the slab to the right of the chimney, although sections of that cliff are steep and sometimes overhanging at the bottom.
content.protection: Standard trad rack. There are no fixed anchors on top. Use long webbing or a static rope to establish a natural anchor (trees & boulders).
content.location: On the far right of the Lower Pitbull Cliff is a section of lower angle rock with a number of cracks.

content.description:
This is the right of three routes located around the corner on Pitbull Cliff.  Ascend an arete for two bolts, moving left to the sport anchors around mid-height.  It shares the last bolt and anchors with

Where Children Play

(11c/d). This is hard and heady.
content.protection: Three bolts, sport anchors. Use an alpine draw for the second bolt.
content.location: Around the corner from Pitbull Cliff proper, it is the most right of three routes in this section of the cliff.
